content: I am a coastal physical oceanographer specializing in coastal submesoscale (1-10 km) processes with an interest in interdisciplinary research linking fluid dynamics to biogeochemistry in the coastal environment. I am also a big fan of turbulent and mixing processes in coastal zones. I use a hierarchy of ocean modeling tools, including ROMS (RANS), DIABLO (LES), DEDALUS (CFD solver in spectral methods), and GOTM (turbulence model), to combine with theories to explore coastal oceans. I am currently a graduate research assistant in Oceanography at Texas A&M University working with Prof. Robert Hetland.

summary: Wind is a primary forcing agent for river plume variability. Consequently, the temporal resolution of wind forcing is an important factor to consider for river plume simulations. This study evaluates river plume simulation errors caused by temporal subsampling of wind forcing data. We use an idealized model of a river plume over a continental shelf and force the model with temporally filtered winds to quantify the effect of temporal subsampling on simulation accuracy. The simulation error is proportional to the fraction of energy missing in the high-frequency wind absent from the forcing. These results set requirements for temporal wind resolution in realistic simulations of river plumes. Spectral analysis of observed wind records at the Mississippi River, Columbia River, and Merrimack River regions indicates that, for simulation errors due to insufficient temporal wind resolution to be smaller than 5 percent of the variance, 3-hourly or 4-hourly wind data are reasonable. Though horizontal variations in wind forcing are lost, analyzing FFT spectrum of a single-point wind measurement in the simulation region is helpful for estimating simulation errors due to temporal resolution, and hence aid in properly selecting temporal resolutions.
title: Temporal resolution of wind forcing required for river plume simulations
Near-inertial waves at submesoscale coherent vortices in a buoyancy-driven flow

summary: The primary goal of this study is to investigate the asymmetric structure of continental shelf wave in a semienclosed double‐shelf basin, such as the Yellow Sea. Supported by in situ observations and realistic numerical simulations, it is found that in the Yellow Sea, the shelf wave response to the synoptic wind forcing does not match the mathematically symmetric solution of classic double‐shelf wave theory, but rather exhibits a westward shift. To study the formation mechanism of this asymmetric structure, an idealized model was used and two sets of experiments were conducted. The results confirm that the asymmetric structure is due to the existence of a topographic waveguide connecting both shelves. For a semienclosed basin, such as the Yellow Sea, a connection at the end of the basin eliminates the potential vorticity barrier between the two shelves and hence plays a role as a connecting waveguide for shelf waves. This waveguide enables the shelf wave to propagate from one shelf to the other shelf and produces the asymmetric response in sea level and upwind flow evolutions.
title: The asymmetric continental shelf wave in response to the synoptic wind burst in a semienclosed double-shelf basin

The Texas-Louisiana shelf in the northern Gulf of Mexico is an ideal, geophysical lab to study near-inertial waves (NIWs) within submesoscale vortices. It is a broad, shallow shelf characterized by large inputs of fresh water from the Mississippi River. Submesoscale vortices within the river plume front are prevalent over the shelf in summertime, coexisting with strong NIWs generated by the land-sea breeze.
The figure below shows the ray tracing within an anti-cyclone over the shelf based on a realistic numerical simulation; it suggests that the enhanced mixing in the stratified interior is highly related to the downward radiation of NIWs and the consequent wave trapping within the anti-cyclone. Wave rays converge where the interior mixing is strongest, and the wave amplification can create strong shear to trigger instabilities, turbulence, and mixing.
summary: Enhanced mixing caused by the trapping of near-inertial waves within submesoscale vortices.
title: Mixing by wave trapping

The Northern South China Sea Forecast System is a fully operational ocean circulation forecast model on the northern shelf of South China Sea based on the Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS). The system provides real-time analysis and 7-day forecast data for investigating coastal environments in that region. The model domain covers the entire Pearl River region and the northern shelf of South China Sea with a resolution of 1800m in the horizontal and 30 layers in the vertical. The water depth ranges from 5m to more than 3000m. The forecast simulation is initialized in 2017. The analysis and forecast fields of surface heat, momentum, and salt flux are provided by the Global Forecast System - NOAA. The ocean open boundary conditions are operationally created based on the Copernicus - Marine Environment Monitoring Service. The real-time river discharge data are operationally parsed from the National Hydrologic Information Center - China Hydrology.
The model has 3-hourly outputs of temperature, salinity, sea level, and currents, which are posted on the Data Portal.
summary: An operational high-resolution ocean circulation forecast model on the northern shelf of South China Sea.
title: Northern South China Sea Forecast System

The hindcast is based on the Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS). The model domain covers the entire Pearl River region and the northern shelf of South China Sea with a resolution of 1800m in the horizontal (white lines in the figure above mark every 10 grid spaces) and 30 layers in the vertical. The water depth ranges from 5m to more than 3000m. The hindcast mode is initialized on January 1, 2007 and run to present, with the initial and open boundary conditions created from the Copernicus - Marine environment monitoring service. The surface heat, momentum, and salt fluxes are provided by the ERA-Interim.
The model is non-assimilative to preserve original hydrodynamic features. The model performance on SST in different regions has been assessed based on the Multi-scale Ultra-high Resolution Sea Surface Temperature satellite data (see the figure below).
summary: A high-resolution ocean circulation hindcast in the northern of South China sea since 2007.
title: Northern South China Sea Hindcast

Coastal buoyancy-driven flows are often associated with stronger lateral density gradients than open ocean fronts, but are seldom observed to be associated with instabilities; in particular, baroclinic instabilities are seldom observed in river plumes, even though lateral buoyancy gradients within the fronts are strong. That contrasts the classical quasi-geostrophic (QG) theory of buoyancy-driven flow over a sloping bottom that predicts unconditional instability growth – the QG assumption may not be reasonable in submesoscale, energetic coastal fronts. We extend the classical non-geostrophic theory to the scenario with a sloping bottom; the adapted theory predicts the suppression of instabilities and indicates that the slope Burger number is the parameter controlling the suppression.
The figure below shows the comparisons between the numerical and theoretical growth rates based on QG theory and non-geostrophic theory (numerical growth rates are calculated based on a series of non-linear numerical simulations). The non-geostrophic theory predicts more accurate growth rates than the QG theory.
summary: Non-geostrophic baroclinic instability over sloping bathymetry.
title: Submesoscale baroclinic instabilities

summary: Recent observations demonstrate the transport and heat advection of the Kuroshio Current have been increasing during the past decades. However, the global pattern of wind stress implies that the wind stress curl at the latitudes of the Kuroshio Current region decreases during the past 30 years. This contrasts to the classical Island Rule theory, which predicts that the transport of the Kuroshio Current should be proportional to the wind stress curl at the latitudes of this region. This study attempts to address this discrepancy by adapting the classical theory to the scenario with a continental shelf slope around an island. Numerical experiments based on a barotropic model are also conducted to investigate the dynamical mechanism. The primary finding is that the wind stress curl at the higher latitudes controls the transport around the island rather than the one at the same latitudes as demonstrated in the classical theory. The physical mechanism is dealing with the propagation of Rossby waves. The waveguide of the Rossby waves is modified by the topographic beta effect of the shelf such that the modulating signals are in fact coming from the higher latitudes than the island region. Consequently, the transport around an island is regulated by the wind at higher latitudes in the scenario with a continental shelf around the island.
title: Effect of the continental shelf slope around island on the Island Rule
